what: Preprocessing and Analyzing Web Tracking Data
title: Preprocessing and Analyzing Web Tracking Data
text: webtrackR R package preprocess analyze web tracking data, .e., web browsing histories participants academic study. Web tracking data oftentimes collected analyzed conjunction survey data participants. R package built top data.table can thus comfortably handle large datasets.

title: Preprocessing and Analyzing Web Tracking Data
text: can install development version webtrackR GitHub : CRAN version can installed :

title: Preprocessing and Analyzing Web Tracking Data
text: package defines S3 class called wt_dt inherits functionality data.table class. summary print method included package. row web tracking data set represents visit. Raw data need least following variables: panelist_id: individual data collected url: URL visit timestamp: time URL visit function .wt_dt assigns class wt_dt raw web tracking data set. also allows specify name raw variables corresponding panelist_id, url timestamp. Additionally, turns timestamp variable POSIXct format. preprocessing functions check three variables present. Otherwise error thrown.

title: Preprocessing and Analyzing Web Tracking Data
text: Several variables can derived raw data following functions: add_duration() adds variable called duration based sequence timestamps. basic logic duration visit set time difference subsequent visit, unless difference exceeds certain value (defined argument cutoff), case duration replaced NA user-defined value (defined replace_by). add_session() adds variable called session, groups subsequent visits session difference next visit exceeds certain value (defined cutoff). extract_host(), extract_domain(), extract_path() extracts host, domain path raw URL adds variables named accordingly. See function descriptions definitions terms. drop_query() lets drop query fragment components raw URL. add_next_visit() add_previous_visit() adds previous next URL, domain, host (defined level) new variable. add_referral() adds new variable indicating whether visit referred social media platform. Follows logic Schmidt et al., 2023. add_title() downloads title website (text within <title> tag web site’s <head>) adds new variable. add_panelist_data(). Joins data set containing information participants survey.

title: Preprocessing and Analyzing Web Tracking Data
text: classify_visits() categorizes website visits either extracting URL’s domain host matching list domains hosts, matching list regular expressions visit URL.

title: Preprocessing and Analyzing Web Tracking Data
text: deduplicate() flags drops (defined argument method) consecutive visits URL within user-defined time frame (set argument within). Alternatively dropping flagging visits, function aggregates durations duplicate visits. sum_visits() sum_durations() aggregate number durations visits, participant time period (set argument timeframe). Optionally, function aggregates number / duration visits certain class visits. sum_activity() counts number active time periods (defined timeframe) participant.

title: Preprocessing and Analyzing Web Tracking Data
text: typical workflow including preprocessing, classifying aggregating web tracking data looks like (using -built example data):
code: library(webtrackR)  # load example data and turn it into wt_dt data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking)  # add duration wt <- add_duration(wt)  # extract domains wt <- extract_domain(wt)  # drop duplicates (consecutive visits to the same URL within one second) wt_dedup <- deduplicate(wt, within = 1, method = "drop")  # load example domain classification and classify domains data("domain_list") wt <- classify_visits(wt, classes = domain_list, match_by = "domain")  # load example survey data and join with web tracking data data("testdt_survey_w") wt <- add_panelist_data(wt, testdt_survey_w)  # aggregate number of visits by day and panelist, and by domain class wt_summ <- sum_visits(wt, timeframe = "date", visit_class = "type")

title: Preprocessing and Analyzing Web Tracking Data
text: package also contains functions analysis web tracking data. One example analysis audience networks (Mangold & Scharkow, 2020). functionalities added later versions package. cutoff indicates minimal duration needed count URL website visit. type can one “pmi”, “phi”, “disparity”, “sdsm”, “fdsm”

what: Add time spent on a visit in seconds — add_duration
title: Add time spent on a visit in seconds — add_duration
text: add_duration() approximates time spent visit based difference two consecutive timestamps, replacing differences exceeding cutoff value defined replace_by.

title: Add time spent on a visit in seconds — add_duration
code: add_duration(   wt,   cutoff = 300,   replace_by = NA,   last_replace_by = NA,   device_switch_na = FALSE,   device_var = NULL )

title: Add time spent on a visit in seconds — add_duration
text: wt webtrack data object. cutoff numeric (seconds). duration greater value, reset value defined replace_by. Defaults 300 seconds. replace_by numeric. Determines whether differences greater cutoff set NA, value. Defaults NA. last_replace_by numeric. Determines whether last visit individual set NA, value. Defaults NA. device_switch_na boolean. Relevant data collected multiple devices. visits ordered timestamp sequence, two consecutive visits can come different devices, makes timestamp difference less likely true duration. may preferable set duration visit NA (TRUE) rather difference next timestamp (FALSE). Defaults FALSE. device_var character. Column indicating device. Required 'device_switch_na' set TRUE. Defaults NULL.

title: Add time spent on a visit in seconds — add_duration
text: webtrack data.table (ordered panelist_id timestamp) columns wt new column called duration.

title: Add time spent on a visit in seconds — add_duration
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) wt <- add_duration(wt) # Defining cutoff at 10 minutes, replacing those exceeding cutoff to 5 minutes, # and setting duration before device switch to `NA`: wt <- add_duration(wt,   cutoff = 600, replace_by = 300,   device_switch_na = TRUE, device_var = "device" )

what: Add the next visit as a new column — add_next_visit
title: Add the next visit as a new column — add_next_visit
text: add_next_visit() adds subsequent visit, determined order timestamps new column. next visit can added either full URL, extracted host extracted domain, depending level.

title: Add the next visit as a new column — add_next_visit
Add the next visit as a new column — add_next_visit
text: wt webtrack data object. level character. Either "url", "host" "domain". Defaults "url".

title: Add the next visit as a new column — add_next_visit
text: webtrack data.table columns wt new column called url_next,host_next domain_next.

title: Add the next visit as a new column — add_next_visit
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) # Adding next full URL as new column wt <- add_next_visit(wt, level = "url") # Adding next host as new column wt <- add_next_visit(wt, level = "host") # Adding next domain as new column wt <- add_next_visit(wt, level = "domain")

what: Add social media referrals as a new column — add_referral
title: Add social media referrals as a new column — add_referral
text: Identifies whether visit referred social media adds new column. See details method.

title: Add social media referrals as a new column — add_referral
Add social media referrals as a new column — add_referral
text: wt webtrack data object. platform_domains character. vector platform domains referrers identified. Order length must correspondent patterns argument patterns character. vector patterns referrers identified. Order length must correspondent platform_domains vector.

title: Add social media referrals as a new column — add_referral
text: webtrack data.table columns wt new column called referral, takes NA referral identified, name specified platform_domains referral platform identified

title: Add social media referrals as a new column — add_referral
text: identify referrals, rely method described valid Schmidt et al.: domain preceding visit platform question, query string visit's URL contains certain pattern, count referred visit. Facebook, pattern identified Schmidt et al. 'fbclid=', although can change future.

title: Add social media referrals as a new column — add_referral
text: Schmidt, Felix, Frank Mangold, Sebastian Stier Roberto Ulloa. "Facebook Avenue News: Comparison Validation Approaches Identify Facebook Referrals". Working paper.

title: Add social media referrals as a new column — add_referral
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) wt <- add_referral(wt, platform_domains = "facebook.com", patterns = "fbclid=") wt <- add_referral(wt,   platform_domains = c("facebook.com", "twitter.com"),   patterns = c("fbclid=", "utm_source=twitter") )

title: Add a session variable — add_session
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) # Setting cutoff to 30 minutes wt <- add_session(wt, cutoff = 1800)

title: Download and add the
Download and add the
text: wt webtrack data object. lang character (language tag). Language accepted request. Defaults "en-US,en-GB,en". Note likely still obtain titles different ones seen originally user, language also depend user's IP device settings.

title: Download and add the
text: webtrack data.table columns wt new column called "title", NA title retrieved.

title: Download and add the
text: title website (text within <title> tag web site's <head>) #' text shown "tab" looking website browser. can contain useful information URL's content can used, example, classification purposes. Note may take run function large number URLs.

title: Download and add the
code: if (FALSE) { data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking)[1:2] # Get titles with `lang` set to default English wt_titles <- add_title(wt) # Get titles with `lang` set to German wt_titles <- add_title(wt, lang = "de") }

what: Create incidence matrix for two-mode networks including audiences — audience_incidence
title: Create incidence matrix for two-mode networks including audiences — audience_incidence
text: audience_incidence() created incidence matrix, matrix entries [,j]=1 panelist visited web site j least . Web site can defined, example, URL's domain, host.

title: Create incidence matrix for two-mode networks including audiences — audience_incidence
Create incidence matrix for two-mode networks including audiences — audience_incidence
text: wt webtrack data object. mode2 character. Name column includes second mode (e.g., domain host) cutoff visits cutoff considered visit.

title: Create incidence matrix for two-mode networks including audiences — audience_incidence
text: Incidence matrix two-mode network

title: Create incidence matrix for two-mode networks including audiences — audience_incidence
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) wt <- add_duration(wt) wt <- suppressWarnings(extract_domain(wt)) # create incidence matrix using domains as second mode incidence <- audience_incidence(wt) # create incidence matrix using hosts as second mode wt <- suppressWarnings(extract_host(wt)) incidence <- audience_incidence(wt, mode2 = "host")

text: audience network

title: Create audience networks — audience_network
Create audience networks — audience_network
text: wt webtrack data object mode2 character. name column includes second mode (e.g. 'domain' 'host') cutoff visits cutoff considered visit type one "pmi", "phi", "disparity", "sdsm, ""fdsm". alpha significance level

title: Create audience networks — audience_network
text: audience network igraph object

title: Create audience networks — audience_network
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) wt <- add_duration(wt) wt <- suppressWarnings(extract_domain(wt)) network <- audience_network(wt, type = "pmi", cutoff = 120)

what: Classify visits by matching to a list of classes — classify_visits
title: Classify visits by matching to a list of classes — classify_visits
text: classify_visits() categorizes visits either extracting visit URL's domain host matching list domains hosts; matching list regular expressions visit URL.

title: Classify visits by matching to a list of classes — classify_visits
code: classify_visits(   wt,   classes,   match_by = "domain",   regex_on = NULL,   return_rows_by = NULL,   return_rows_val = NULL )

title: Classify visits by matching to a list of classes — classify_visits
text: wt webtrack data object. classes data.table containing classes can matched visits. match_by character. Whether match list entries classes domain visit ("domain") host ("host") exact match; regular expression whole URL visit ("regex"). set "domain" "host", wt classes need column called accordingly. set "regex", url column wt used, need set regex_on column classes pattern matching. Defaults "domain". regex_on character. Column classes use pattern matching. Defaults NULL. return_rows_by character. column classes subset returning data. Defaults NULL. return_rows_val character. value columns specified return_rows_by, data returned. example, classes data contains column type, value called "shopping", setting return_rows_by "type" return_rows_val "shopping" return visits classified "shopping".

title: Classify visits by matching to a list of classes — classify_visits
text: webtrack data.table columns wt column classes except column specified match_by.

title: Classify visits by matching to a list of classes — classify_visits
code: data("testdt_tracking") data("domain_list") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) # classify visits via domain wt_domains <- extract_domain(wt, drop_na = FALSE) #> Warning: Domain could not be extracted for 161 rows. Set drop_na = TRUE to drop these rows. wt_classes <- classify_visits(wt_domains, classes = domain_list, match_by = "domain") # classify visits via domain # for the example, just renaming "domain" column domain_list$host <- domain_list$domain wt_hosts <- extract_host(wt, drop_na = FALSE) #> Warning: Host could not be extracted for 161 rows. Set drop_na = TRUE to drop these rows. wt_classes <- classify_visits(wt_hosts, classes = domain_list, match_by = "host") # classify visits with pattern matching # for the example, any value in "domain" treated as pattern data("domain_list") regex_list <- domain_list[type == "facebook"] wt_classes <- classify_visits(wt[1:5000], classes = regex_list,                               match_by = "regex", regex_on = "domain") # classify visits via domain and only return class "search" data("domain_list") wt_classes <- classify_visits(wt_domains, classes = domain_list,                               match_by = "domain", return_rows_by = "type",                               return_rows_val = "search")

code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) wt <- extract_domain(wt) #> Warning: Domain could not be extracted for 161 rows, which were dropped from the data. Set drop_na = FALSE to keep these rows. code_urls <- "https://dkr1.ssisurveys.com/tzktsxomta" create_urldummy(wt, dummy = code_urls, name = "test_dummy") #> # webtrack data: 49,451 × 7 #>    panelist_id  wave timestamp           url            device domain test_dummy #>    <chr>       <int> <dttm>              <chr>          <chr>  <chr>  <lgl>      #>  1 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:47 https://dkr1.… mobile ssisu… TRUE       #>  2 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:49 https://roiro… mobile decip… FALSE      #>  3 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:50 https://roiro… mobile decip… FALSE      #>  4 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:50 https://roiro… mobile decip… FALSE      #>  5 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:53 https://roiro… mobile decip… FALSE      #>  6 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:53 https://roiro… mobile decip… FALSE      #>  7 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:53 https://roiro… mobile decip… FALSE      #>  8 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:59 https://roiro… mobile decip… FALSE      #>  9 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:59 https://roiro… mobile decip… FALSE      #> 10 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:59 https://roiro… mobile decip… FALSE      #> # ℹ 49,441 more rows

title: Deduplicate visits — deduplicate
text: deduplicate() flags, drops aggregates duplicates, defined consecutive visits URL within certain time frame.

title: Deduplicate visits — deduplicate
code: deduplicate(   wt,   method = "aggregate",   within = 1,   duration_var = "duration",   keep_nvisits = FALSE,   same_day = TRUE )

title: Deduplicate visits — deduplicate
text: wt webtrack data object. method character. One "aggregate", "flag" "drop". set "aggregate", consecutive visits (matter time difference) URL combined duration aggregated. case, duration column must specified via "duration_var". set "flag", duplicates within certain time frame flagged new column called duplicate. case, within argument must specified. set "drop", duplicates dropped. , within argument must specified. Defaults "aggregate". within numeric (seconds). method set "flag" "drop", subsequent visit defined duplicate happening within time difference. Defaults 1 second. duration_var character. Name duration variable. Defaults "duration". keep_nvisits boolean. method set "aggregate", determines whether number aggregated visits kept variable. Defaults FALSE. same_day boolean. method set "aggregate", determines whether count visits consecutive day. Defaults TRUE.

title: Deduplicate visits — deduplicate
text: webtrack data.table columns wt updated duration

title: Deduplicate visits — deduplicate
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) wt <- add_duration(wt, cutoff = 300, replace_by = 300) # Dropping duplicates with one-second default wt_dedup <- deduplicate(wt, method = "drop") # Flagging duplicates with one-second default wt_dedup <- deduplicate(wt, method = "flag") # Aggregating duplicates wt_dedup <- deduplicate(wt[1:1000], method = "aggregate") # Aggregating duplicates and keeping number of visits for aggregated visits wt_dedup <- deduplicate(wt[1:1000], method = "aggregate", keep_nvisits = TRUE)

what: Extract the domain from URL — extract_domain
title: Extract the domain from URL — extract_domain
text: extract_domain() adds domain URL new column. "domain", mean "top private domain", .e., domain public suffix (e.g., "com") defined Public Suffix List. See details. Extracts domain urls.

title: Extract the domain from URL — extract_domain
Extract the domain from URL — extract_domain
text: wt webtrack data object. varname character. Name column extract host. Defaults "url". drop_na boolean. Determines whether rows host can extracted dropped data. Defaults TRUE.

title: Extract the domain from URL — extract_domain
text: webtrack data.table columns wt new column called 'domain' (, varname equal 'url', '<varname>_domain')

title: Extract the domain from URL — extract_domain
text: define "web domain" common colloquial meaning, , part web address identifies person organization control. google.com. technically, mean "domain" "top private domain", .e., domain public suffix, defined Public Suffix List. Note definition sometimes leads counterintuitive results public suffixes "registry suffixes". , controlled domain name registrar, allow users directly register domain. One example public, non-registry suffix blogspot.com. URL like www.mysite.blogspot.com, function, indeed packages aware , extract domain mysite.blogspot.com, although might think blogspot.com domain. details, see

title: Extract the domain from URL — extract_domain
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) # Extract domain and drop rows without domain wt <- extract_domain(wt) #> Warning: Domain could not be extracted for 161 rows, which were dropped from the data. Set drop_na = FALSE to keep these rows. # Extract domain and keep rows without domain wt <- extract_domain(wt, drop_na = FALSE)

text: extract_host() adds host URL new column. host defined part following scheme (e.g., "https://") preceding subdirectory (anything following next "/"). Note URL entries like chrome-extension://soomething http://192.168.0.1/something, result set NA.

code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) # Extract host and drop rows without host wt <- extract_host(wt) #> Warning: Host could not be extracted for 161 rows, which were dropped from the data. Set drop_na = FALSE to keep these rows. # Extract host and keep rows without host wt <- extract_host(wt, drop_na = FALSE)

Extract the path from URL — extract_path
text: wt webtrack data object varname character. name column extract host. Defaults "url".

title: Extract the path from URL — extract_path
text: webtrack data.table columns wt new column called 'path' (, varname equal 'url', '<varname>_path')

title: Extract the path from URL — extract_path
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) # Extract path wt <- extract_path(wt)

title: Isolation Index — isolation_index
text: Given two groups (B) individuals, isolation index captures extent group disproportionately visit websites whose visitors also members group .

title: Isolation Index — isolation_index
Isolation Index — isolation_index
text: grp_A vector (usually corresponds column webtrack data.table) indicating number individuals group using website grp_B vector (usually corresponds column webtrack data.table) indicating number individuals group B using website

title: Isolation Index — isolation_index
text: numeric value 0 1. 0 indicates isolation 1 perfect isolation

title: Isolation Index — isolation_index
text: value 1 indicates websites visited group group B overlap. value 0 means visit exactly websites

title: Isolation Index — isolation_index
text: Cutler, David M., Edward L. Glaeser, Jacob L. Vigdor. "rise decline American ghetto." Journal political economy 107.3 (1999): 455-506. Gentzkow, Matthew, Jesse M. Shapiro. "Ideological segregation online offline." Quarterly Journal Economics 126.4 (2011): 1799-1839.

title: Isolation Index — isolation_index
code: # perfect isolation left <- c(5, 5, 0, 0) right <- c(0, 0, 5, 5) isolation_index(left, right) #> [1] 1  # perfect overlap left <- c(5, 5, 5, 5) right <- c(5, 5, 5, 5) isolation_index(left, right) #> [1] 0

title: Summarize activity per person — sum_activity
Summarize activity per person — sum_activity
text: wt webtrack data object. timeframe character. Indicates time frame aggregate visits. Possible values "date", "week", "month", "year" "wave". set "wave", wt must contain column call wave. Defaults "date".

title: Summarize activity per person — sum_activity
text: data.table columns panelist_id, column indicating number active time units.

title: Summarize activity per person — sum_activity
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) # summarize activity by day wt_sum <- sum_activity(wt, timeframe = "date")

what: Summarize visit duration by person — sum_durations
title: Summarize visit duration by person — sum_durations
text: sum_durations() summarizes duration visits person within timeframe, optionally visit_class visit. Note: time frame rows NA duration column, summarized duration time frame NA. rows time frame NA duration column, function ignore NA rows. visits class (.e., value 'visit_class' column) time frame, summarized duration time frame zero; visits, NA duration, summarized duration NA.

title: Summarize visit duration by person — sum_durations
code: sum_durations(wt, var_duration = NULL, timeframe = NULL, visit_class = NULL)

title: Summarize visit duration by person — sum_durations
text: wt webtrack data object. var_duration character. Name duration variable already present. Defaults NULL, case duration approximated add_duration(wt, cutoff = 300, replace_by = "na", replace_val = NULL) timeframe character. Indicates time frame aggregate visit durations. Possible values "date", "week", "month", "year", "wave" NULL. set "wave", wt must contain column call wave. Defaults NULL, case output contains duration visits entire time. visit_class character. Column contains classification visits. value column, output column indicating number visits belonging value. Defaults NULL.

title: Summarize visit duration by person — sum_durations
text: data.table columns panelist_id, column indicating time unit (unless timeframe set NULL), duration_visits indicating duration visits (seconds, whatever unit variable specified var_duration parameter), column value visit_class, specified.

title: Summarize visit duration by person — sum_durations
code: data("testdt_tracking") wt <- as.wt_dt(testdt_tracking) # summarize for whole period wt_summ <- sum_durations(wt) # summarize by week wt_summ <- sum_durations(wt, timeframe = "week") # create a class variable to summarize by class wt <- suppressWarnings(extract_domain(wt, drop_na = TRUE)) wt[, google := ifelse(domain == "google.com", 1, 0)] #> # webtrack data: 49,451 × 7 #>    panelist_id  wave timestamp           url                device domain google #>    <chr>       <int> <dttm>              <chr>              <chr>  <chr>   <dbl> #>  1 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:47 https://dkr1.ssis… mobile ssisu…      0 #>  2 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:49 https://roirocket… mobile decip…      0 #>  3 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:50 https://roirocket… mobile decip…      0 #>  4 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:50 https://roirocket… mobile decip…      0 #>  5 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:53 https://roirocket… mobile decip…      0 #>  6 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:53 https://roirocket… mobile decip…      0 #>  7 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:53 https://roirocket… mobile decip…      0 #>  8 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:59 https://roirocket… mobile decip…      0 #>  9 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:59 https://roirocket… mobile decip…      0 #> 10 AiDS4k1rQZ      1 2019-02-28 19:09:59 https://roirocket… mobile decip…      0 #> # ℹ 49,441 more rows wt_summ <- sum_durations(wt, timeframe = "week", visit_class = "google")

code: as.wt_dt(   x,   timestamp_format = "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%OS",   varnames = c(panelist_id = "panelist_id", url = "url", timestamp = "timestamp") )  is.wt_dt(x)

title: An S3 class, based on data.table, to store web tracking data — wt_dt
text: x data.frame containing necessary set columns, namely panelist's ID, visit URL visit timestamp. timestamp_format string. Specifies raw timestamp's formatting. Defaults "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%OS". varnames Named vector column names, contain panelist's ID (panelist_id), visit's URL (url) visit's timestamp (timestamp).

title: An S3 class, based on data.table, to store web tracking data — wt_dt
text: webtrack data object least columns panelist_id, url timestamp logical. TRUE x webtrack data object FALSE otherwise

title: An S3 class, based on data.table, to store web tracking data — wt_dt
text: wt_dt table data.table. Therefore, can used function work data.frame data.table. operation variable creation, subsetting joins inherited data.table [] operator, following convention DT[,j,] (see data table package detail).

webtrackR 0.1.0
text: added preprocessing functions add_session(), extract_host(), extract_domain(), extract_path(), add_next_visit(), add_previous_visit(), add_title(), add_referral() changed example data something realistic added unit tests (#65) added filtering, summarizing, aggregating functions
